utterances.speaker: SWAN

utterances.sentences: What? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.sentences: OK. Bishop, I have a question. He actually did it. Does that count at all?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: Well - it absolutely counts Laura.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: OK. That's good.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: And the entire team of Van Jones and those who worked with him--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Right, Van Jones worked with him. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: --on getting that passed.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: That was smart.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: That piece of legislation will have benefits to African Americans and people across this spectrum.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: So why would a racist do that?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: And so there is no doubt.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: What would a racist do that?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: Well, Laura, because someone got a piece of legislation passed, does not mean that we ignore a long 40-year history. And what I can't believe is that, you all are telling me from the channel who - one of your Anchor's said when Trayvon Martin was killed that, "If you don't want to be perceived as a thug you shouldn't wear a hoodie". if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } From you all who said that black young men who wear hoodies should have a certain perception to tell me that a MAGA hat should not viewed in a certain way - it's absolutely hypocritical.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Bishop, I have to say - I think - putting aside your comments about the channel. I think you're making a really good point about profiling people based on what they wear. I think that's an excellent point. You shouldn't profile. Someone wants to wear a hoodie, let him wear a darn hoodie. Someone wants to wear a Hillary button or a Bernie button or a Bernie hat or - good for them. It's their political expression. I don't judge them on the clothes they wear, you shouldn't. And if I've ever done that, I'm wrong. But I think we have to apply that standard across the board. And I actually think that you actually can work with President Trump--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: And we agree on that.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I think you could actually work with President Trump on a lot of issues. I'm not saying that to try to be cute here. I actually think, if you and Bongino and Trump got together in a room, I bet you guys could do some really good things together. I really do. This conversation about what's racist-- How about solutions? Let's help each other get this country on the right track. I think you could actually do it, I really do. I think you got a lot of passion, got a lot of supporters.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump has solutions, Laura. A lot of black men and women are working right now, because of Donald Trump and are supporting their kids-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.sentences: Well, there were lot of black men and women who are working before Trump came into office. Let's not pretend that--

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: No kidding--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: --the unemployment rate being drop down 16.8 percent down 7.8 percent under Obama, before Trump ever came into office.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: The economy right now is - you know, your comment is so ridiculous--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: It dropped another 1 percent under Trump--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: But again, I'm trying - OK.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: So no - when you try to give him credit for what someone else did, that's what's absolutely.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Right, right, give him right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I think in the end--

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: Racial tensions were high under Barack Obama - very hot.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Guys, I think in the end, people - we all do this, I do this too. You kind - you want to see the world in the way that you absolutely believe it has to be at that moment. We all do it. But I'm saying on national television, I really believe if people just think about what works, basic things that work. OK, probably having some immigration laws work, because we want to protect our people. We want to have - some better trade policies will probably help all Americans. Like how do we get from A to B and who can get us there. And I just think, a lot of times we're talking past each other and I think it's sad. And I think people watching a lot of these shows, they get sad.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: But, Laura, let me ask you a question, though, how - I agree with you. And I would love - I started this debate with an open mind with the gentleman, and I still have an open mind. But how do you talk to someone who claims when you put a MAGA hat on that you're the worst scum on the planet, which would be a racist.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: Well, those are your words. Don't put words in my mouth. Don't put words in my mouth. I'm well able to articulate for myself. I'm well able to articulate for myself and I didn't say that, you said that. But let's not sit here and pretend that symbols don't have meaning.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: This is the whole basis of your commentary.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: Let's not sit here and pretend that things have meanings - that symbols don't have meanings.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right, guys.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: And the MAGA hat has a meaning, it's a sign that is attached to Donald Trump and everything that he stand for.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Guys, we are out of time. But I can say that there are hundreds of thousands of Americans who have those hats, and I think it's really dangerous for any of us to judge them as individuals based on the fact that they voted for President Trump, because they just thought he had better ideas. Not that they're not bad people.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: Well, those young men didn't vote. They are not old enough to vote.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I mean, there are always bad people in every group. All right, there are lot of bad people in every group, I get that.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.sentences: They are old enough to think.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: But I just think we should profile people based on the clothes they wear. I should do it, I don't think anyone should do it. I think it's bad, and I think it's toxic. But I really - we might get somewhere eventually. But I really appreciate both of you joining us. Thank you both. I probably talked too much in this segment. But that's what I want.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.sentences: Thanks Laura.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right. Could those who threatened those Covington teens be charged with domestic terrorism? A prosecutor from Kentucky joins us next exclusively to explain. Plus President Trump's defiance saying, "He'll deliver a State of the Union next week even if it's not on Capitol Hill. Steve Scalise will join us, Andy Biggs also here. And where the President could make the next speech?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Covington Catholic School has reopened but the violent threats against the students have not stopped. In fact, the Covington Diocese received a suspicious package just tonight. We share tweet after tweet with you from celebrities, liberal commentators calling for attacks and even the death of these teenagers. Tonight some hope that this hate speech will not go unpunished. Joining me now exclusively for his first national television interview, is Rob Sanders. He's a prosecutor for Kenton County, Kentucky where Covington Catholic High is located. Rob, it's good to see you. What kind of charges could realistically be filed and against whom?

utterances.speaker: ROB SANDERS, KENTON COUNTY, KENTUCKY PROSECUTOR
utterances.sentences: Well, we have a number of different charges in Kentucky that might apply. The one that jumps out the fastest is terroristic threatening. Now there's three different degrees of terroristic threatening in Kentucky, two of them are felonies. The most common one, I think that might apply in this situation is terroristic threatening second-degree, that's any time that someone threatens death or violence against a educational institution in Kentucky or any student in the educational institution in connection with the school function. Now that is a Class D felony. It's one to five years in the state penitentiary. That could rise to five to ten years in a Class C felony if the person threatens that violence or death in connection to an educational institution in it the use of a device of mass destruction or weapon of mass destruction.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, you have - this is happening on Twitter though.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: --that would double up the--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Mr. Sanders, this is happening on Twitter from different states.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: --different locations, does that hinder the prosecution? I mean you don't really need an - I mean, you have to interview these people, they're in different states. You're going to have to get to them somehow.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Well, it makes it much more difficult. It makes it much more difficult, much more complicated, #1. There's a number of misdemeanors that could apply in a lot of these cases, but we can't reach across state lines and extradite for misdemeanors--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: --which means, we would have to wait for the person to come back to Kentucky or make a stop in Kentucky before we could ever arrest them. But when it comes to the offenses that rise to the felony level, we can extradite. Now it's not as easy as staying a Twitter handle. We can't reach out and just arrest someone who - half the time they're using a fake name, fake profile picture that sort of thing. We have to go through a process of issuing subpoenas, search warrants, getting--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Are you going to do this?

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: --information that goes with - it's already underway. I've had detectives in and out of my office all day today. We were starting with some comments, some threats that were made in state, because those are people that we don't even have to extradite. And we are moving on then to the ones that are out of state. We've had the detective that works in my office has already been busy issuing Grand Jury Subpoenas and composing search warrants for detectives at other agencies.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Good.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: --sending out, so we can get the information associated with the ownership of these accounts.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: We get the IP addresses that are registered--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: You got to get these people.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Then we find out.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I mean, it's only - you are only one office--

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: That's right, we find out who uses the internet, those IP addresses.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Yes, we get the IP addresses. We're going to follow-up with you later in the week to find out where you are on this. But--

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: --this has to happen. Because, until people--

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Well, it's going to happen. Everybody's got to realize that these- -

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: --have to got jail. They have to go to jail. That's got to hurt. Otherwise someone is getting hurt and I fear - we're about to talk to Steve Scalise who felt it in a different way. Someone is going to get hurt or someone is going to get killed. Prosecutor, I really appreciate you joining us.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, there is no doubt.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: And we'll have you back. I know it's a longer segment. We've got a lot of people to talk to, so we appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF., SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE
utterances.sentences: Let's work together on a mutually agreeable dates and welcome you to the Capitol to get a State of the Union address. Government is still shutdown. I still make the offer.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Just so you know, she uses on the basis of the shutdown - when she asked me to make the address, she did it during the shutdown, well into the shutdown by a couple of weeks, so the shutdown was going on. Now she is blaming the shutdown.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Well, the gloves are off, and the State of the Union in the House Chamber has officially been canceled. Very adult of Nancy Pelosi. But if you thought Trump was backing down, think again. There's going to be some version of the State of the Union next Tuesday, whatever they call it. It's not called the State of the Union, but it's not going to be on Capitol Hill. Here now, House Minority Whip Steve Scalise and Congressman Andy Biggs. Congressmen, you both offered the president an alternate location. Congressman Scalise, where?

utterances.speaker: REP. STEVE SCALISE, R-LA, HOUSE MINORITY WHIP
utterances.sentences: Frankly, I think the president ought to do a State of the Union, and let him choose. We've talked but a number of locations. But ultimately it's the message that is so important. This is about securing the border of our country. Clearly Nancy Pelosi doesn't want the American people to hear the president's message. But you know what, Laura, the American people want to hear the president's message. Nancy Pelosi can't stop this. It just shows how petty she is and how disgraceful this action is. She will go down as the first speaker in the history of our country -- George Washington gave addresses to Congress. This is a constitutional requirement. She's now going to have stain on her record.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: He could do it in writing, though, right?

utterances.speaker: SCALISE
utterances.sentences: The President is still going to give a State of the Union, and frankly I think a lot more people will listen to it now and hear the message about why it's so important to protect our border.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Why is she afraid of the people hearing the president and what he's going to say? Congressman Biggs, you have an idea. What is it?

utterances.speaker: REP. ANDY BIGGS, R-ARIZ
utterances.sentences: Yes. We've invited the president to come to Arizona. It's a border state. It's a great backdrop. He is loved in Arizona. I don't want it to be a rally. I want it to be a true State of the Union, but let's do it -- why not do it in a friendly environment? Bring the Democrats in. Maybe they'll go to the border and see what's really going on and understand the crisis as well.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Very interesting. Congressman, also a surprising twist, there appear to be some defections among the Democrats who may have just had about enough of this shutdown. Watch.

utterances.speaker: SEN. MARK WARNER, D-VA
utterances.sentences: I know we are going to have to add additional border security. Where folks say we need additional barrier protections, I'm all for it.

utterances.speaker: REP. STENY HOYER, D-MD, HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER
utterances.sentences: Physical barriers are part of the solution.

utterances.speaker: NEIL CAVUTO, HOST
utterances.sentences: So you don't share Nancy Pelosi's view that a wall is immoral?

utterances.speaker: HOYER
utterances.sentences: It's protecting people. It's moral.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Give Trump the money. I would give the whole thing that he wants and put strings on it so that you make sure he puts the ball where it needs to be. Why are we fighting over this? We are going to build that wall anyway at some time.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I think the president is getting some push from certain quarters, it's all turning against you. Everyone is blaming you. You've got to give in. You've got to stop. I think he's doing exactly what needs to be done. It's a lot like the Obamacare thing. The longer you let this thing play out, the more clear it becomes what a crisis this is and we need to do something.

utterances.speaker: SCALISE
utterances.sentences: Laura, the American people are for securing the border. And if you look, President Trump is gaining momentum because people are seeing what this is about. Frankly, these kind of actions by Nancy Pelosi only heighten the awareness of what's going on. And the more she does this, she's got more of our own Democrats in her party that are moving away from her. They are taking a dangerous position by opposing border security. They are on the wrong side of this issue.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: They don't want a wall. Repair some existing fences. But the 30 more centrist Democrats wrote a letter to Pelosi, right? That's not nothing. There are cracks in this resolve on their part.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I talked to them on the floor. I try to get out of my echo chamber, and a lot of them are like, well, you know, maybe we need to move on. And I think that's part of it. They just want to move on and resolve it. And I'm not sure how keen they are on building a wall. They just want to resolve the issue to get the government open.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: I also think, look, a lot of people, it's been a month they haven't been paid. That's a rough deal for a lot of people. They need to get paid. And they need to have their jobs, and they want to do their jobs. And really, it's not great for this to continue to go on for anybody.

utterances.speaker: SCALISE
utterances.sentences: We need to reopen the government and we need to secure the border. We can do both. President Trump has worked overtime to come up with different ideas. Nancy Pelosi has not offered one single alternative. And now she thinks by holding the State of the Union hostage, she's going to be able to win this. The people in this country want to see the border secure. She is on the wrong side.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Freshman Congressman, Democrats on the House government -- or Oversight Committee, I guess, right, it's the Oversight Committee. So you've got Ilhan Omar, she's from Minnesota. She's quite a firebrand. And a number of others who are -- they've got them all. Pressley, a Democrat, Ayanna Pressley from Massachusetts, Tlaib, these are far left, very popular in their own way. How's that going to be different on committee life?

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.sentences: You know what, the reality is they have kind of stacked that committee for the one reason they are there. It's to impeach the president. If they can't impeach them, they want to force him out somehow. That won't happen. The bare minimum is to try to embarrass him. That's really what it is. And they want to further try to delegitimize President Trump. That's the whole purpose of that committee now. That's the way they've structured the rules and their membership. That's where they are going.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Well, we are going to be following at every step of the way. We hope the president delivers the State of the Union. I hope he delivers it at Ellis Island. How about that. That would be great.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: Have you seen Best Picture nominees, any of you guys? Can you name any of them? Our own Raymond Arroyo took to the streets to ask people if they saw any of these films. You won't believe the reaction, "Seen and Unseen."

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: It's time for our "Seen and Unseen" segment where we expose the big cultural stories of the day. Oh, well, we hit the streets to find out who you thought will win Best Picture at the Oscars or if you've actually seen any of these movies. Plus, the personal days and nights of a certain Congressional star. Joining us now, all the details, Raymond Arroyo, FOX News contributor, "New York Times" bestselling author of the upcoming book, fantastic, "Will Wilder, Amulet of Power." Raymond, you hit the streets today.

utterances.speaker: RAYMOND ARROYO, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: I did indeed.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.sentences: It was a little warmer for you. What did you find out?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.sentences: Laura, last year's Academy Awards ceremony, I don't have to tell you, watching was the lowest on record, down from even the year before. These films used to bring the country together. So I took to the streets to see if people had seen these eight Best Picture nominees. When I found was surprising.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.sentences: Are you excited about any of the Best Picture nominees for the Academy Awards?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I don't know anything about them.

utterances.utterance: --but where kids have been threatened, badly threatened. Dan Bongino, did these boys, standing there did they trigger this behavior on the part of this activist - that we're learning a lot more about tonight, by the way, and the Black Hebrew Israelites. Did they trigger them with these MAGA hats? DAN BONGINO, HOST OF "DAN BONGINO SHOW": Laura, with due respect your other guest, I have no idea what he's talking about. I have a monitor in my office. I mean, we're all watching the same - it's like we live in a post- fact Bizarro World universe. You have a kid standing there in a MAGA hat with a political expression on it motionless, with the smile on his face, while an adult confronts the kid and yet I don't know what tape the bishop is watching. What did these kids do wrong? And then to throw in this random fact and I'm using the dreaded air (ph) quotes because it's an anti-fact, a non-fact that someone scream this about rape which they did, but they were not part of that group, is clearly either an effort to distract from the lack of a point which, I don't believe the gentleman has, or to distract from the video on the screen that we can all see. These were a bunch of kids waiting for a bus while a group of activist confronted them. What video are you watching, I don't understand.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Well, if you want to pretend if - I was watching the same video you were watching. And if you want to pretend that the few moments where Mr. Sandmann was standing in front of Mr. Phillips--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What was he doing?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: --say all and the be all to the video, then go right ahead. But there's a lot more to the video than just that one point.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: --and you cannot sit here and tell me that these young men were not ridiculing, that they were not jeering, that they were not mocking.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Bishop, you're man of a cloth--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: That's obvious. That's what I see.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Bishop you're a man of the cloth.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And I know you don't advocate - you don't advocate violence and you don't - and you agree, I would imagine, that nonviolent standing there, even wearing a piece of clothing that people find objectionable is not grounds for them threatening to kill them, to burn them, to destroy their lives, to dox them?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Well, Laura, you and I completely agree - you and I completely agree that there's no excuse of anybody threatening to kill or to burn or to harm anyone. Matter of fact, I've been getting death threats and phone calls from people on the other side, because of my tweets. I emphatically condemned that type of behavior. But I also condemned the type of behavior that I saw from those young men on that particular day.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What were they doing? They were standing there Bishop.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: And if we want to - they were not standing there. Are you and I seeing the same video? Are you not seeing those young men--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What is Nick Sandmann doing? Nick Sandmann didn't speak.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: We're not talking - Nick Sandmann was not there by himself. There was an entire group of young men who were mocking, they were jeering, they were ridiculing--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: They were reacting. They were reacting to being called incest babies--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: And for you all that sit here and pretend that we don't hear that--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Well, it wasn't Philips who called them that.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: They were being called incest babies--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: And you can't - what you can't do--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes. OK. All right--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: --what you cannot do is blame their behavior on what their interaction with the Hebrew Israelites were--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So someone should - OK, so people should be called incest babies and crackers and swear words, and not be able to - not respond. And when they do respond, they're the ones. I mean, first--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: At the beginning-- INGRAHAM: --of all, I mean, Nick Sandmann didn't say a thing. And those other kids weren't part of the school. But I got to ask you a simple question.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Laura at the beginning--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Is the MAGA hat - simple question, Bishop, is the MAGA hat racist?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Well, at the beginning I condemn the behavior of the Hebrew Israelites, so let's not pretend you all--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right. Is the MAGA hat racist?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: When it comes to the MAGA hat, it's a piece of clothing that represents Donald Trump and everything that comes along with Donald Trump. Donald Trump--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So is that a yes?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: --what is an unrepentant racist. He is an unrepentant racist.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: The MAGA hat, to many, is representative of a Klan Hood or various other symbols--

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: --of racism. Absolutely. It absolutely is.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: How, how--

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: What's going on here? Is this real? Did he just say that on a cable television? Bishop--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: I absolutely said that.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: --I don't want to - I not willing to defer to the man of god line to you anymore after you just said one of the dumbest comments--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Well, it really doesn't matter what you refer to me as you don't define me.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: That is the dumbest thing I have ever hear in seven years of doing cable news that Make America Great Again, by the way, a slogan used by Bill Clinton at times too--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Reagan - that was Reagan's time by the way--

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: --is racist? Are you serious?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: But let me--

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: So let me get this straight. Donald Trump - wait, wait hold on - I didn't interrupt you. So Donald Trump who gives you back more of your money, has fought for school choice, has black unemployment at the lowest in modern American history we've seen. Donald Trump, if he's a racist, he's the worst racist we've seen in American history--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Criminal justice reform--

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: And call this--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Come on, come on - Donald Trump--

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: Are you serious? I'm embarrassed for you and you should be too.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Donald Trump calls African nations A-- hole nations.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: No, he calls third world nations--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Donald Trump calls Mexicans rapists. Donald Trump calls black athletes sons of (EXPLETIVE).

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Bishop. Bishop. Hold on guys. Hold on, hold on--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: --that the racism that oozes from Donald Trump has not happened?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. Bishop, I have a question. Is the Criminal Justice Reform Legislation that is passed into law which President Obama wanted to do, I think George Bush talked about, which civil rights leaders for years have been trying to get people to pass. He actually did it. Does that count at all?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Well - it absolutely counts Laura.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: OK. That's good.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: And the entire team of Van Jones and those who worked with him--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Right, Van Jones worked with him.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: --on getting that passed.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: That was smart.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: That piece of legislation will have benefits to African Americans and people across this spectrum.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: So why would a racist do that?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: And so there is no doubt.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What would a racist do that?

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Well, Laura, because someone got a piece of legislation passed, does not mean that we ignore a long 40-year history. And what I can't believe is that, you all are telling me from the channel who - one of your Anchor's said when Trayvon Martin was killed that, "If you don't want to be perceived as a thug you shouldn't wear a hoodie". From you all who said that black young men who wear hoodies should have a certain perception to tell me that a MAGA hat should not viewed in a certain way - it's absolutely hypocritical.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Bishop, I have to say - I think - putting aside your comments about the channel. I think you're making a really good point about profiling people based on what they wear. I think that's an excellent point. You shouldn't profile. Someone wants to wear a hoodie, let him wear a darn hoodie. Someone wants to wear a Hillary button or a Bernie button or a Bernie hat or - good for them. It's their political expression. I don't judge them on the clothes they wear, you shouldn't. And if I've ever done that, I'm wrong. But I think we have to apply that standard across the board. And I actually think that you actually can work with President Trump--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: And we agree on that.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I think you could actually work with President Trump on a lot of issues. I'm not saying that to try to be cute here. I actually think, if you and Bongino and Trump got together in a room, I bet you guys could do some really good things together. I really do. This conversation about what's racist-- How about solutions? Let's help each other get this country on the right track. I think you could actually do it, I really do. I think you got a lot of passion, got a lot of supporters.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: Donald Trump has solutions, Laura. A lot of black men and women are working right now, because of Donald Trump and are supporting their kids--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Well, there were lot of black men and women who are working before Trump came into office. Let's not pretend that--

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: No kidding--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: --the unemployment rate being drop down 16.8 percent down 7.8 percent under Obama, before Trump ever came into office.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: The economy right now is - you know, your comment is so ridiculous--

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: It dropped another 1 percent under Trump--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But again, I'm trying - OK.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: So no - when you try to give him credit for what someone else did, that's what's absolutely.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: Right, right, give him right.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I think in the end--

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: Racial tensions were high under Barack Obama - very hot.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Guys, I think in the end, people - we all do this, I do this too. You kind - you want to see the world in the way that you absolutely believe it has to be at that moment. We all do it. But I'm saying on national television, I really believe if people just think about what works, basic things that work. OK, probably having some immigration laws work, because we want to protect our people. We want to have - some better trade policies will probably help all Americans. Like how do we get from A to B and who can get us there. And I just think, a lot of times we're talking past each other and I think it's sad. And I think people watching a lot of these shows, they get sad.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: But, Laura, let me ask you a question, though, how - I agree with you. And I would love - I started this debate with an open mind with the gentleman, and I still have an open mind. But how do you talk to someone who claims when you put a MAGA hat on that you're the worst scum on the planet, which would be a racist.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Well, those are your words. Don't put words in my mouth. Don't put words in my mouth. I'm well able to articulate for myself. I'm well able to articulate for myself and I didn't say that, you said that. But let's not sit here and pretend that symbols don't have meaning.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: This is the whole basis of your commentary.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Let's not sit here and pretend that things have meanings - that symbols don't have meanings.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right, guys.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: And the MAGA hat has a meaning, it's a sign that is attached to Donald Trump and everything that he stand for.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Guys, we are out of time. But I can say that there are hundreds of thousands of Americans who have those hats, and I think it's really dangerous for any of us to judge them as individuals based on the fact that they voted for President Trump, because they just thought he had better ideas. Not that they're not bad people.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Well, those young men didn't vote. They are not old enough to vote.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I mean, there are always bad people in every group. All right, there are lot of bad people in every group, I get that.

utterances.speaker: BONGINO
utterances.utterance: They are old enough to think.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But I just think we should profile people based on the clothes they wear. I should do it, I don't think anyone should do it. I think it's bad, and I think it's toxic. But I really - we might get somewhere eventually. But I really appreciate both of you joining us. Thank you both. I probably talked too much in this segment. But that's what I want.

utterances.speaker: SWAN
utterances.utterance: Thanks Laura.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right. Could those who threatened those Covington teens be charged with domestic terrorism? A prosecutor from Kentucky joins us next exclusively to explain. Plus President Trump's defiance saying, "He'll deliver a State of the Union next week even if it's not on Capitol Hill. Steve Scalise will join us, Andy Biggs also here. And where the President could make the next speech?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Covington Catholic School has reopened but the violent threats against the students have not stopped. In fact, the Covington Diocese received a suspicious package just tonight. We share tweet after tweet with you from celebrities, liberal commentators calling for attacks and even the death of these teenagers. Tonight some hope that this hate speech will not go unpunished. Joining me now exclusively for his first national television interview, is Rob Sanders. He's a prosecutor for Kenton County, Kentucky where Covington Catholic High is located. Rob, it's good to see you. What kind of charges could realistically be filed and against whom?

utterances.speaker: ROB SANDERS, KENTON COUNTY, KENTUCKY PROSECUTOR
utterances.utterance: Well, we have a number of different charges in Kentucky that might apply. The one that jumps out the fastest is terroristic threatening. Now there's three different degrees of terroristic threatening in Kentucky, two of them are felonies. The most common one, I think that might apply in this situation is terroristic threatening second-degree, that's any time that someone threatens death or violence against a educational institution in Kentucky or any student in the educational institution in connection with the school function. Now that is a Class D felony. It's one to five years in the state penitentiary. That could rise to five to ten years in a Class C felony if the person threatens that violence or death in connection to an educational institution in it the use of a device of mass destruction or weapon of mass destruction.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, you have - this is happening on Twitter though.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: --that would double up the--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Mr. Sanders, this is happening on Twitter from different states.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --different locations, does that hinder the prosecution? I mean you don't really need an - I mean, you have to interview these people, they're in different states. You're going to have to get to them somehow.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: Well, it makes it much more difficult. It makes it much more difficult, much more complicated, #1. There's a number of misdemeanors that could apply in a lot of these cases, but we can't reach across state lines and extradite for misdemeanors--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: --which means, we would have to wait for the person to come back to Kentucky or make a stop in Kentucky before we could ever arrest them. But when it comes to the offenses that rise to the felony level, we can extradite. Now it's not as easy as staying a Twitter handle. We can't reach out and just arrest someone who - half the time they're using a fake name, fake profile picture that sort of thing. We have to go through a process of issuing subpoenas, search warrants, getting--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Are you going to do this?

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: --information that goes with - it's already underway. I've had detectives in and out of my office all day today. We were starting with some comments, some threats that were made in state, because those are people that we don't even have to extradite. And we are moving on then to the ones that are out of state. We've had the detective that works in my office has already been busy issuing Grand Jury Subpoenas and composing search warrants for detectives at other agencies.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Good.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: --sending out, so we can get the information associated with the ownership of these accounts.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: We get the IP addresses that are registered--

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: You got to get these people.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: Then we find out.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I mean, it's only - you are only one office--

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: That's right, we find out who uses the internet, those IP addresses.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, we get the IP addresses. We're going to follow-up with you later in the week to find out where you are on this. But--

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --this has to happen. Because, until people--

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: Well, it's going to happen. Everybody's got to realize that these- -

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: --have to got jail. They have to go to jail. That's got to hurt. Otherwise someone is getting hurt and I fear - we're about to talk to Steve Scalise who felt it in a different way. Someone is going to get hurt or someone is going to get killed. Prosecutor, I really appreciate you joining us.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, there is no doubt.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And we'll have you back. I know it's a longer segment. We've got a lot of people to talk to, so we appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF., SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE
utterances.utterance: Let's work together on a mutually agreeable dates and welcome you to the Capitol to get a State of the Union address. Government is still shutdown. I still make the offer.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Just so you know, she uses on the basis of the shutdown - when she asked me to make the address, she did it during the shutdown, well into the shutdown by a couple of weeks, so the shutdown was going on. Now she is blaming the shutdown.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, the gloves are off, and the State of the Union in the House Chamber has officially been canceled. Very adult of Nancy Pelosi. But if you thought Trump was backing down, think again. There's going to be some version of the State of the Union next Tuesday, whatever they call it. It's not called the State of the Union, but it's not going to be on Capitol Hill. Here now, House Minority Whip Steve Scalise and Congressman Andy Biggs. Congressmen, you both offered the president an alternate location. Congressman Scalise, where?

utterances.speaker: REP. STEVE SCALISE, R-LA, HOUSE MINORITY WHIP
utterances.utterance: Frankly, I think the president ought to do a State of the Union, and let him choose. We've talked but a number of locations. But ultimately it's the message that is so important. This is about securing the border of our country. Clearly Nancy Pelosi doesn't want the American people to hear the president's message. But you know what, Laura, the American people want to hear the president's message. Nancy Pelosi can't stop this. It just shows how petty she is and how disgraceful this action is. She will go down as the first speaker in the history of our country -- George Washington gave addresses to Congress. This is a constitutional requirement. She's now going to have stain on her record.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: He could do it in writing, though, right?

utterances.speaker: SCALISE
utterances.utterance: The President is still going to give a State of the Union, and frankly I think a lot more people will listen to it now and hear the message about why it's so important to protect our border.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Why is she afraid of the people hearing the president and what he's going to say? Congressman Biggs, you have an idea. What is it?

utterances.speaker: REP. ANDY BIGGS, R-ARIZ
utterances.utterance: Yes. We've invited the president to come to Arizona. It's a border state. It's a great backdrop. He is loved in Arizona. I don't want it to be a rally. I want it to be a true State of the Union, but let's do it -- why not do it in a friendly environment? Bring the Democrats in. Maybe they'll go to the border and see what's really going on and understand the crisis as well.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Very interesting. Congressman, also a surprising twist, there appear to be some defections among the Democrats who may have just had about enough of this shutdown. Watch.

utterances.speaker: SEN. MARK WARNER, D-VA
utterances.utterance: I know we are going to have to add additional border security. Where folks say we need additional barrier protections, I'm all for it.

utterances.speaker: REP. STENY HOYER, D-MD, HOUSE MAJORITY LEADER
utterances.utterance: Physical barriers are part of the solution.

utterances.speaker: NEIL CAVUTO, HOST
utterances.utterance: So you don't share Nancy Pelosi's view that a wall is immoral?

utterances.speaker: HOYER
utterances.utterance: It's protecting people. It's moral.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Give Trump the money. I would give the whole thing that he wants and put strings on it so that you make sure he puts the ball where it needs to be. Why are we fighting over this? We are going to build that wall anyway at some time.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I think the president is getting some push from certain quarters, it's all turning against you. Everyone is blaming you. You've got to give in. You've got to stop. I think he's doing exactly what needs to be done. It's a lot like the Obamacare thing. The longer you let this thing play out, the more clear it becomes what a crisis this is and we need to do something.

utterances.speaker: SCALISE
utterances.utterance: Laura, the American people are for securing the border. And if you look, President Trump is gaining momentum because people are seeing what this is about. Frankly, these kind of actions by Nancy Pelosi only heighten the awareness of what's going on. And the more she does this, she's got more of our own Democrats in her party that are moving away from her. They are taking a dangerous position by opposing border security. They are on the wrong side of this issue.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: They don't want a wall. Repair some existing fences. But the 30 more centrist Democrats wrote a letter to Pelosi, right? That's not nothing. There are cracks in this resolve on their part.

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I talked to them on the floor. I try to get out of my echo chamber, and a lot of them are like, well, you know, maybe we need to move on. And I think that's part of it. They just want to move on and resolve it. And I'm not sure how keen they are on building a wall. They just want to resolve the issue to get the government open.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: I also think, look, a lot of people, it's been a month they haven't been paid. That's a rough deal for a lot of people. They need to get paid. And they need to have their jobs, and they want to do their jobs. And really, it's not great for this to continue to go on for anybody.

utterances.speaker: SCALISE
utterances.utterance: We need to reopen the government and we need to secure the border. We can do both. President Trump has worked overtime to come up with different ideas. Nancy Pelosi has not offered one single alternative. And now she thinks by holding the State of the Union hostage, she's going to be able to win this. The people in this country want to see the border secure. She is on the wrong side.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Freshman Congressman, Democrats on the House government -- or Oversight Committee, I guess, right, it's the Oversight Committee. So you've got Ilhan Omar, she's from Minnesota. She's quite a firebrand. And a number of others who are -- they've got them all. Pressley, a Democrat, Ayanna Pressley from Massachusetts, Tlaib, these are far left, very popular in their own way. How's that going to be different on committee life?

utterances.speaker: BIGGS
utterances.utterance: You know what, the reality is they have kind of stacked that committee for the one reason they are there. It's to impeach the president. If they can't impeach them, they want to force him out somehow. That won't happen. The bare minimum is to try to embarrass him. That's really what it is. And they want to further try to delegitimize President Trump. That's the whole purpose of that committee now. That's the way they've structured the rules and their membership. That's where they are going.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, we are going to be following at every step of the way. We hope the president delivers the State of the Union. I hope he delivers it at Ellis Island. How about that. That would be great.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Have you seen Best Picture nominees, any of you guys? Can you name any of them? Our own Raymond Arroyo took to the streets to ask people if they saw any of these films. You won't believe the reaction, "Seen and Unseen."

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
